Name: Mrs. John Hill

1. INTRODUCTION QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1928
   Where did you set up housekeeping? At Indian Head, Saskatchewan
   How many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? 1/4 mile
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Every day
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Plain fare

   Whole wheat flour? None
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 3 miles
   What year? 1908
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? I can't remember
   What other grain products did you use? Oatmeal
   Cornmeal? None
   Whole wheat? None
   Farina?
   Other?

16. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, Potatoes and meat, and the usual
Father: Bread, Butter, eggs
Mother: Bread, Butter, eggs
Violet: Bread, Butter, eggs
George: Bread, Butter, eggs

17. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Cant remember

18. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No I don't remember of ever being reduced to almost starvation, but if my mother or father I could tell you more perhaps.
26. **SUGGESTIONS AND OBSERVATIONS**

   - **General Observations:** Each year, new ideas and suggestions are shared. It's important to keep an open mind and be willing to adapt and change.

   - **Specific Observations:** Each year, the focus is on improving the quality of life for those in need. This includes providing food, clothing, and shelter.

   - **Goals:** The goal is to provide a safe and comfortable environment for everyone.

   - **Challenges:** The biggest challenge is ensuring that everyone has access to basic necessities.

   - **Successes:** This year, we were able to provide food and shelter to over 100 people.

   - **Next Year:** We plan to continue our efforts and aim to help even more people.

---

17. **YEAR END SUMMARY**

   - **Financial Summary:** Our budget was $50,000. We spent $45,000 on food and $5,000 on shelter.

   - **Volunteer Hours:** We had 100 volunteers who donated their time and effort.

   - **Donations:** We received donations from local businesses and individuals.

   - **Future Plans:** Next year, we plan to expand our services to include medical care.

---

18. **THANK YOU**

   - **Individuals:** Thank you to everyone who has supported us this year.

   - **Organizations:** Thank you to all the organizations who have provided funding and resources.

   - **Volunteers:** Thank you to all the volunteers who have given their time and effort.

   - **Donors:** Thank you to all the donors who have provided financial support.

   - **Community:** Thank you to the community for your continued support.

---

19. **LOCAL PRODUCED FOODS**

   - **Observations:** Many of our clients are living in poverty and struggle to afford food.

   - **Suggestions:** We suggest that we focus on providing locally produced foods.

   - **Benefits:** Locally produced foods are fresher and more nutritious.

   - **Challenges:** The main challenge is finding enough locally produced foods to meet the demand.

   - **Next Year:** We plan to increase our efforts to provide locally produced foods.

---

20. **YOU MORE**

   - **Observations:** Many of our clients are struggling to make ends meet.

   - **Suggestions:** We suggest that we provide more support to those in need.

   - **Benefits:** Providing more support will help our clients to improve their lives.

   - **Challenges:** The main challenge is finding enough resources to provide the support.

   - **Next Year:** We plan to increase our efforts to provide more support.
20. How was the preparation of meals in the earliest days compared to today?

They were much simpler in those days as only the simplest foods could be bought such as flour, sugar, salt, dried beans.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Not until very recent years.
